content: "http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2009/03/29/abortions_vasectomies_on_increase_in_economic_crisis/?page=full" quote: The pregnant woman showed up at the medical center in flip-flops and tears after walking there to save bus fare. Her boyfriend had lost his job, she told her doctor in Oakland, Calif., and now - fearing harder times for her family - she wanted to abort what would have been her fourth child. "This was a desired pregnancy - she'd been getting prenatal care - but they reevaluated expenses and decided not to continue," said Dr. Pratima Gupta. "When I was doing the options counseling, she interrupted me halfway through, crying, and said, 'Dr. Gupta, I just walked here for an hour. I'm sure of my decision.' " Other doctors are hearing similarly wrenching tales. For many Americans, the recession is affecting their most intimate decisions about sex and family planning. Doctors and clinics are reporting that many women are choosing abortions and men are having vasectomies because they cannot afford a child. Planned Parenthood of Illinois clinics performed an all-time high number of abortions in January, many of them motivated by the women's economic worries, said Steve Trombley, chief executive officer, who declined to give exact numbers. Abortions at Planned Parenthood's St. Louis-area clinics were up nearly 7 percent in the second half of 2008 from a year earlier - ending a stretch in which the numbers were dwindling. Planned Parenthood said it has no up-to-date national abortion figures, nor do other private or government agencies. Stephanie Poggi of the National Network of Abortion Funds, which helps women in need pay for abortions, said, however, that calls to the network's national helpline have nearly quadrupled from a year ago. "A lot of women who never thought they'd need help are turning to us," Poggi said. "They're telling us: 'I've already put off paying my rent, my electric bill. I'm cutting back on my food.' They've run through all the options."... Dr. J. Stephen Jones, a urologist at the Cleveland Clinic, said he has seen a surge of men seeking vasectomies, with his monthly caseload rising from about 45 to more than 70 since November. He said most of the men were married, had children, decided they couldn't afford more, and opted to get a vasectomy while they still had job-related health insurance. "Several articulated very forcefully that the economy was the motive," Jones said. "I have a long discussion with them and ask if there's any chance they still might want kids. They say they know it's time." Women - which may be more important to you - feeding and clothing the children you already have - or carrying your fetus to term? Men - would your employment/financial condition affect your decision on whether to get a vasectomy or not?
quote: The pregnant woman showed up at the medical center in flip-flops and tears after walking there to save bus fare. Her boyfriend had lost his job, she told her doctor in Oakland, Calif., and now - fearing harder times for her family - she wanted to abort what would have been her fourth child. "This was a desired pregnancy - she'd been getting prenatal care - but they reevaluated expenses and decided not to continue," said Dr. Pratima Gupta. "When I was doing the options counseling, she interrupted me halfway through, crying, and said, 'Dr. Gupta, I just walked here for an hour. I'm sure of my decision.' " Other doctors are hearing similarly wrenching tales. For many Americans, the recession is affecting their most intimate decisions about sex and family planning. Doctors and clinics are reporting that many women are choosing abortions and men are having vasectomies because they cannot afford a child. Planned Parenthood of Illinois clinics performed an all-time high number of abortions in January, many of them motivated by the women's economic worries, said Steve Trombley, chief executive officer, who declined to give exact numbers. Abortions at Planned Parenthood's St. Louis-area clinics were up nearly 7 percent in the second half of 2008 from a year earlier - ending a stretch in which the numbers were dwindling. Planned Parenthood said it has no up-to-date national abortion figures, nor do other private or government agencies. Stephanie Poggi of the National Network of Abortion Funds, which helps women in need pay for abortions, said, however, that calls to the network's national helpline have nearly quadrupled from a year ago. "A lot of women who never thought they'd need help are turning to us," Poggi said. "They're telling us: 'I've already put off paying my rent, my electric bill. I'm cutting back on my food.' They've run through all the options."... Dr. J. Stephen Jones, a urologist at the Cleveland Clinic, said he has seen a surge of men seeking vasectomies, with his monthly caseload rising from about 45 to more than 70 since November. He said most of the men were married, had children, decided they couldn't afford more, and opted to get a vasectomy while they still had job-related health insurance. "Several articulated very forcefully that the economy was the motive," Jones said. "I have a long discussion with them and ask if there's any chance they still might want kids. They say they know it's time."

content: quote: Most women feel that if they don't have a child then they are not really a woman at all. How sick is that? As a woman, I think that's the damn dumbest thing I've ever heard! Some of these chicks who think they HAVE to have kids....WHY? Honestly, if you don't have a child, are you less of a person? Hell no! Anyways...she has the right to do with her body/child as she wishes, BUT, I myself think she's being selfish and unreasonable. If you can plan a child, then you can carry through with its birth! If you and your boyfriend (don't get me started on THAT) can plan to have 4 kids (or THAT either!), then you damn sure shoulda thought of how you'd raise 'em if things got tight. My husband and I have 5 between us, yes on purpose, and even when things are tight the kids were always provided for first. How? Well he and I went without material things, he got a 2nd job and so did I, he pawned expensive music equipment. Whatever it took, because what was the other option? Sell a couple of 'em? Do what so many in Nebraska did and give them up? NO. It's called consequences of actions. She got some action and didn't wanna deal with the consequences anymore when it got the littlest bit challenging. Raising kids oughta be a rude awakening for someone who doesn't rise to challenges, but instead bails on 'em! That's my 2 cents. Flame away if ya want.

reply: How Sophie's Choice of you. (To a much less extreme extent) It was not a choice I would have made, but I am not in these women's shoes so I cannot say what is the best decision for them...and it IS their choice.
title: Abortions & Vasectomies on the increase due to economy

content: quote: Women - which may be more important to you - feeding and clothing the children you already have - or carrying your fetus to term? Men - would your employment/financial condition affect your decision on whether to get a vasectomy or not? The child is hers, born or not. It is a living human being in her womb. As to feeding a child, we have programs for that. We also have long waiting lists for babies. Is death really the preferred alternative to adoption? Economic hard times come and go. Generally in the U.S. starvation due to economic hardship doesn't exist. By the logic of this article, Barack Obama Jr. would have been aborted. Alcoholic absent father, mother with no means of support. Why on earth did she not abort our President? If only Planned Parenthood were there, think of how much better our world would be, right?

title: Abortions & Vasectomies on the increase due to economy

content: my parents had 5 kids..helped with grandchildren, etc. they both said the last of us was a surprise..but in the long haul the expenses from 4 to 5 didn't change that much..of course as we got older if we wanted extras, we earned money to buy..never expected everything to be handed to us..we went from 2 to 3 children & the expense didn't change much either..just my 2 cents & not even worth that much anymore!

You called her killer, suggesting she should kill her kids. You demean her in her hour of trial. Men have absolutely NO RIGHT to comment about abortion. If men wore a rubber or got a vasectomy every time it made sense to do it, abortion would be no problem. It's a woman's problem, made so by MEN. Self-righteousness doesn't flatter Holy Willy. Dear billbright, the last portion of your name is a misnomer, IMHO. (note: rapes or incest have nothing to do with my postings below.) Any woman, and I repeat ANY woman, that does not wish to carry a pregnancy to term, is nothing more than an "egg donor", in the same as any man that is unwilling to raise and/or support a child that they helped create is a "sperm donor" (Do notice the emphasis on 'helped'. In almost all of the abortion cases, it was adult consensual sex.) Both of the persons, who engaged in an adult, consensual, sexual relation that produces a child, have a say about the child's future; and if either one of them wishes to have the child carried to term, it shall be so!! ( My personal opinion is that the child shall be born regardless of their wishes, unless deemed to be a medical safety issue by a team of at least 5 doctors who are experienced in obstetrics.) To argue that last statement is futile! No argument, I repeat, NO argument, has merit against it. No brag...just fact. see -<http://www.imdb.com/Quotes?0061259> These are my opinions. Yours may differ.
